SMUG.deftext:
self-satisfied, pleased with oneself, complacent

A SMUG person is quite pleased with himself. SMUG people firmly believe they are right or superior, and take delight in being better than others. SMUGNESS is not a very admirable quality.

“Alice felt quite SMUG after she had beaten her brother at tennis.”

“SMUG in his belief that he knew the subject, he didn’t bother studying for the test.”

“She gave her friends a SMUG smile as she walked up to the stage to receive her award.”

Other forms of the word: SMUGNESS, n.

VINDICTIVE.deftext:
vengeful, unforgiving

VINDICTIVE means “showing a desire for revenge.” A VINDICTIVE person by nature wants to get even with anyone who wrongs him.

“She’s a VINDICTIVE person. If she thinks you’ve said something bad about her, she’ll spend weeks trying to get back at you.”

“My father was stern, but he wasn’t VINDICTIVE.”

“He made some VINDICTIVE remarks about his old enemy.”

“We don’t want to be VINDICTIVE; we just want to get back the money he took from us.”

BEDEVIL.deftext:
to torment, harass, annoy, plague

Be- is a prefix which forms verbs out of nouns. To BEDEVIL someone is to treat him devilishly, usually by constantly annoying or worrying him.

“The mosquitoes BEDEVILED us when we camped by the lake.”

“This project has been BEDEVILED by problems since the beginning.”

“She was BEDEVILED by minor illnesses all year.”

In the Pretest, the most commonly chosen incorrect answer is astound, perhaps due to a confusion of BEDEVIL with bedazzle, which means to impress forcefully.

NEGLIGIBLE.deftext:
unimportant, small, not worthy of attention

Anything that is NEGLIGIBLE is able to be neglected without worrying about it, usually because it is so unimportant or tiny.

“The medicine had a NEGLIGIBLE effect. She was no better after taking it than before.”

“His attempts to help us were NEGLIGIBLE. I don’t think he tried very hard.”

“You get a NEGLIGIBLE saving by buying the large economy size. It’s just not worth it.”

EDIFYING.deftext:
uplifting, enlightening, instructive

EDIFYING and its related verb EDIFY are from the same Latin root as edifice, which means “a large and impressive building.” To EDIFY originally meant simply to build. Now it is only used in the sense of “to build up one’s mind or morals.”

An “EDIFYING experience” is one which improves you spiritually or intellectually. It is not necessarily an enjoyable experience, although it may be.

“The teacher said it would be an EDIFYING experience for us to go to the museum.”

“The minister delivered a very EDIFYING sermon.”

Other forms of the word: EDIFY, v. EDIFICATION, n.

MALEFACTOR.deftext:
a criminal, evildoer

MALEFACTOR comes from Latin words meaning “to do evil.” A MALEFACTOR is a criminal, or anyone who does evil to another.

“Some unknown MALEFACTOR broke several windows in the school last night.”

“The MALEFACTORS must not be allowed to get away with their crime.”

The opposite of MALEFACTOR is benefactor, someone who does good to other people.

MUSE.deftext:
to think, meditate, ponder, reflect

To MUSE on or over something is to think silently about it. The word usually suggests a dreamy or wondering attitude rather than serious thought.

“He MUSED on the shortness of human life.”

“She MUSED over the good times they used to have.”

“Sally MUSED about the beauty of nature.”

REPROACH.deftext:
to blame, criticize, rebuke

To REPROACH someone is to find fault with him, especially in a tone that suggests sorrow or the need for sorrow. The idea is often that of shaming a person into being better.

“Jim’s mother REPROACHED him for forgetting her birthday.”

“The teacher REPROACHED the students for not studying harder.”

REPROACH is also a noun, meaning blame or censure. A person whose reputation is “above REPROACH” has never done anything he might be blamed for.

“His criminal activities brought REPROACH on his entire family.”

Other forms of the word: REPROACHFUL, adj.

ENVOY.deftext:
a messenger, agent, deputy, representative

ENVOY is from a French word meaning to send. An ENVOY is a person sent somewhere as a representative of a government, business, group of people, etc.

“We sent him as our ENVOY to meet with our opponents.”

“The ENVOY came to beg us to forgive his king.”

In diplomacy, ENVOY is a specific rank of diplomat, second in importance after an ambassador.

Note the different pronunciations. Sometimes words from foreign languages keep their foreign pronunciation for a long time in English. ENVOY seems to be in the process of changing from the French pronunciation on’-voy to the English en’-voy.

FISSURE.deftext:
a narrow crack or opening

A FISSURE is a long, narrow crack, usually rather deep, and usually made by splitting or breaking.

“The earthquake caused many FISSURES to appear on the sides of the mountain.”

In a broader sense, a FISSURE is a division or disagreement which threatens to break up a group of people.

“A FISSURE developed in the party between those who supported the war and those who opposed it.”

“His stand on unemployment opened up many FISSURES in his previously solid support.”

COALESCE.deftext:
to unite, join together

To COALESCE is to come or grow together into one body or group. COALESCE often suggests a slow or natural process of growing together.

“Over time the land between them was built up and the two islands finally COALESCED.”

“Several small parties managed to COALESCE into one important political organization.”

DELUGE.deftext:
a flood, downpour

A DELUGE is a great flood, usually caused by a tremendous downpour of rain. A DELUGE can also be anything that overwhelms like a flood.

“When the movie star was sick, the hospital received a DELUGE of mail.”

“There was a DELUGE of criticism when the popular teacher was fired.”

DELUGE is also a verb meaning to flood.

“When the dam broke, towns along the river were DELUGED.”

“They DELUGED the company with requests for more information.”

“He was DELUGED with job offers after he graduated from school.”

Battle is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, possibly because DELUGE sometimes has a sense of violence and destructiveness.

FARCICAL.deftext:
absurd, laughable, ridiculous

A FARCE is a comedy, usually one filled with silly characters and unbelievable situations.

“We expected a serious drama, but it turned out to be a light-hearted FARCE.”

A FARCE is also any situation or event that is like such a comedy.

“Everything seemed to go wrong; the entire picnic was a complete FARCE.”

FARCICAL is the adjective from FARCE. Something that is FARCICAL is like a FARCE, so silly and extreme that it is funny.

“His attempts to explain why he was late were almost FARCICAL.”

“It was a FARCICAL game. The players seemed to make up the rules as they went along.”

Other forms of the word: FARCE, n.

SURMISE.deftext:
to guess, suspect, suppose, think

To SURMISE means “to believe without strong evidence,” to guess or suppose.

“He SURMISED that there would be a surprise party for him.”

“The detective SURMISED that the burglars had entered the house through an open window.”

SURMISE is also a noun, which means a guess.

“Her SURMISE proved to be correct.”

ASSENT.deftext:
to agree, consent, concur

To ASSENT to something is to agree to it. ASSENT often does not suggest strong support but a weaker kind of “going along.”

“My father ASSENTED when I asked him if I could go to the movies.”

“I cannot ASSENT to the idea that all men are basically evil.”

“Everyone ASSENTED to the proposal that we have a party.”

ASSENT is also a noun, meaning agreement.

“The teacher gave her ASSENT to our suggestion that we have a class picnic.”

Usage: ASSENT is often followed by to.

questions.prompt: Are SMUG people usually very likable?
Would a VINDICTIVE person hold a grudge?
Is it pleasant to be BEDEVILED?
Would a jackhammer cause a NEGLIGIBLE amount of noise?
Is an EDIFYING experience always an enjoyable one?
Can you MUSE over something unimportant?
Do people often feel sorry after they have been REPROACHED?
Is an ENVOY likely to travel much?
Would three letters be a DELUGE of mail?
Would people be sad at a FARCICAL event?
Can you SURMISE when you aren't certain?
Can a person ASSENT to something he doesn't particularly like?
With a SMUG air of superiority he showed them how to put the puzzle together.
Our VINDICTIVE neighbors built a large fence just to block our view.
Doubts about his decision continued to BEDEVIL him long after it had been made.
Although they worked hard at cleaning the house, the results were NEGLIGIBLE; it was just about as dirty as before.
She only bought top-quality food to EDIFY her family.
He had a secret MALEFACTOR who sent him the money to finish college.
The comedian MUSED us with his jokes.
The car REPROACHED us at seventy miles an hour.
The president sent his personal ENVOY to talk with the king.
The debate over whether to hire him caused a FISSURE in the organization.
The six streams meet and COALESCE into a river.
They DELUGED him with prizes after he won the contest.
His explanation of how electricity works was so obviously wrong it was almost FARCICAL.
From the way Bill was acting, Mary SURMISED that he was unhappy in his new job.
She ASSENTED the fact that he made more money than she did for doing the same job.
